title: 19. Socrates and Democracy
description: Socrates’ critique of Athenian democracy as presented by Plato and Xenophon, including key political analogies.

questions.question: How do Plato and Xenophon present Socrates’ attitude towards democracy?
options: As critical of its reliance on unqualified decision-makers

questions.question: What does Socrates criticise about the democratic selection of officials?
options: Constant turnover prevented the development of expertise

questions.question: According to Socrates, why were democratic voters flawed?
options: They lacked education and rational understanding

questions.question: What effect did popular ignorance have on politicians?
options: It forced politicians to follow popular whims

questions.question: In Plato’s Republic, who should rule the ideal state?
What quality makes philosopher-kings suitable to rule?
In the Ship of State analogy, whom does the ship-owner represent?
What do the quarrelling crew members symbolise?
Why is the navigator dismissed by the crew in the Ship of State?
options: He is labelled a useless stargazer

questions.question: Whom does the navigator represent in Socrates’ analogy?
In the Animal Trainer analogy, what does the ‘beast’ represent?
What does the animal trainer learn to do?
What is the main criticism of speakers in the Assembly?
options: They prioritised popularity over the good of the state

questions.question: Why does Socrates see rhetoric as dangerous in democracy?
Which work contains both analogies discussed in the PPT?
What do both analogies ultimately argue for?
options: Rule by knowledge rather than opinion

questions.question: Why might Socrates’ views have been threatening to democracy?
options: They undermined faith in popular decision-making

questions.question: Overall, how do Plato and Xenophon portray Socrates’ political thought?
